Authors:
Bret M Boyd, Julie M Allen, Nam Nguyen, Pranjal Vachaspati,
Zach Quicksall, Tand Warnow, Lawrence Mugisha, Kevin P. Johnson, David
L. Reed
Title:
Primates, lice, and bacteria: new phylogenomic tree has
implications for cospeciation and genome evolution in the bacterial
symbionts of lice.
Keywords:
Ca. Riesia, endosymbiont replacement, Anoplura, Human
lice, pantothenate
Abstract:
Insects with restricted diets rely on symbiotic bacteria
to provide essential metabolites missing in their diet. The
blood-sucking lice are obligate, host-specific parasites of mammals and
are themselves host to symbiotic bacteria necessary for development. In
human lice, these symbionts supply the lice with B-vitamins. Research
has focused on insect symbionts, because of their small genomes. In
different louse species, novel endosymbionts appear to have replaced
existing endosymbiont. Therefore, louse endoysmbionts could be developed
as a model system to study symbiont genome evolution, by comparing
symbiont genomes that have evolved independently. Here we focus on the
evolutionary relationships of human and primate louse symbionts using a
phylogenomic approach. In contrast to previous studies, we do not find
evidence of a recent symbiont replacement. Instead we support a scenario
of cospeciation with their louse hosts; which is largely driven by
speciation of their mammal hosts. Our results are used to interpret
genome evolution of louse symbionts. We investigate, in detail, the
origins of a plasmid critical to B-vitamin synthesis known from
symbionts of human lice. We find that this plasmid likely originated in
the common ancestor of chimpanzee, human, and gorilla louse symbionts
and persisted through multiple speciation events. This plasmid is absent
in an old world monkey louse symbiont, where this pathway is on its
primary chromosome. This suggests the unique genomic configuration
brought about by the plasmid is not essential for symbiosis, but once it
was obtained, it has persisted.
